author: @marvinbcn2
text: Great video as usual. There's only one sentence that annoys me at 4:19: "The likelihood of p=0,57 given that 4 out of 7 people would randomly prefer Orange Fanta is greater than 0.273, the likelihood when p = 0.5". The sentence seems self-contradictory to me, as p=0,57 is not compatible with random preference (or, using the contrapositive: random preference always implies p = 0,5). P ≠ 0,5 is equivalent to say that preferences are not random. So the  term "randomly" should be ruled out in this sentence. Does my observation make sense?

author: @philippenachtergal6077
text: Hello guys,  what is the best way to compute say the 90% likelihood margin for this real world problem: We have a double blind vaccine test: * 12280 people got a placebo, 90 of them contracted the virus. * 12280 got the vaccine, 5 of them contracted the virus. So we have an efficiency at around 94,5%  How do you compute the error margin around that for a say 90% likelihood ? Do you compute separate margins for the placebo group and for the vaccine group and then divine the lower bound of the margin of the vaccine group by the higher bound of the margin of the other group and vice-versa to get a global margin or is there something more appropriate ?  Side note: I didn't compute it (yet) because excel can't handle things like binomials with a bas like 12280 very well and I don't really have the time to do it more properly.
